wikipedia_page.main: Sir John Brigg DL (21 September 1834 – 30 September 1911), was a British Liberal Party politician.

response: During reform of the Liberals’ local organisation in readiness for implementation of the Redistribution of Seats Act 1885, he was elected a vice-president of the party’s Keighley associationBradford Daily Telegraph, 28 April 1885. The other Vice-President then elected was John Brigg, later MP for Keighley. and was invited to become the Liberal candidate for the new Spen Valley constituency. He accepted the Spen Valley invitation subject to it having the constituency association’s unanimous support. This was withheld by the association’s teetotal faction when Craven would not endorse the Local Option policy (whereby districts could vote to make abstinence compulsory within their boundaries).Manchester Weekly Times, 6 June 1885; Leeds Times, 13 June 1885; Shipley Times and Express, 24 October 1885.

Craven took no active part in politics after 1892 beyond continuing to serve on the West Riding County Council, to which he had been elected in 1889.Leeds Mercury, 22 January 1889. He briefly retained his directorship of the Bradford Banking Company, was appointed a magistrate in 1894 and regularly sat on the Bradford bench during the next ten years.York Herald, 3 April 1894; Shipley Times and Express, 4 December 1914. On the Glorious Twelfth of 1905, aged nearly eighty, he turned out for his fifty-second consecutive season of grouse shooting when he was described as a "wonderful shot for his years".Bradford Daily Telegraph, 18 August 1905. He owned the shooting rights over Lodge Moor in Nidderdale and, together with John Brigg MP, was lessee of Keighley Moor from the Duke of Devonshire: Leeds Mercury, 15 April 1876, 13 August 1881.
The vacancy was caused by the death on 30 September 1911 of Sir John Brigg, who had been the Liberal MP for Keighley since 1895.
